meta.description: Juror Archetype System - Clear definitions and memorable personas

archetypes.one_liner: Personal responsibility hardliner - blames plaintiffs for their own problems
archetypes.core_belief: People are responsible for their own outcomes. Bad things happen because of bad choices, not bad systems or bad corporations.
archetypes.in_deliberation: Will argue plaintiff caused their own injury, minimize damages, and resist emotional appeals. Often vocal and influential.
recognize_by: Stories about overcoming hardship without help
Skepticism about lawsuits or 'lottery justice'
Phrases like 'personal responsibility' or 'nobody forced them'
Business owner, sales, or self-employed background
Conservative politics (though not always)
archetypes.plaintiff_strategy: Must strike. If stuck with one, emphasize defendant's clear rule violations - frame as 'defendant didn't take responsibility.'
archetypes.defense_strategy: Keep as many as possible. They'll do your work for you.

archetypes.one_liner: Anti-corporate warrior - sees case as David vs Goliath
archetypes.core_belief: Corporations and institutions have too much power and harm regular people. The legal system is one of the few ways to hold them accountable.
archetypes.in_deliberation: Will advocate for plaintiff, push for maximum damages including punitives, and frame case as justice issue. May clash with Bootstrappers.
recognize_by: Skepticism of corporations or 'the system'
Union membership or labor movement connection
Social work, nonprofit, education, or advocacy background
Progressive politics, NPR listener, college educated
References to 'power imbalance' or 'accountability'
archetypes.plaintiff_strategy: Keep as many as possible. They'll fight for you.
archetypes.defense_strategy: Must strike. They've already decided corporations are guilty.

archetypes.one_liner: Genuinely fair evaluator - will follow the evidence wherever it leads
archetypes.core_belief: Every case should be decided on its own merits. Both plaintiffs and defendants can be right or wrong depending on the facts.
archetypes.in_deliberation: Will ask clarifying questions, weigh evidence carefully, and may help build consensus. Can be persuaded by strong evidence from either side.
recognize_by: Balanced answers that acknowledge both perspectives
Phrases like 'I'd need to see the evidence'
Moderate or Independent politics
Professional backgrounds requiring objectivity (HR, research, auditing)
Thoughtful, measured speaking style
archetypes.plaintiff_strategy: Keep if you have strong evidence. Win through facts, not emotion.
archetypes.defense_strategy: Keep if plaintiff's case is weak. They won't give sympathy verdicts.

archetypes.one_liner: Dominant leader who will control deliberations - direction depends on their views
archetypes.core_belief: I have expertise/authority that qualifies me to lead this group to the right decision.
archetypes.in_deliberation: Will speak first and most, likely become foreperson, and drive the jury toward their preferred outcome. Other jurors defer to them.
recognize_by: Executive, military, clergy, or leadership background
Speaks confidently and makes eye contact
Suggests procedures or organization
Others look to them before answering
Sits in prominent position
archetypes.key_insight: A Captain's SECONDARY archetype determines if they're dangerous. CEO Carl (Captain + Bootstrapper) = defense weapon. Reverend Ruth (Captain + Crusader) = plaintiff weapon.
archetypes.plaintiff_strategy: Strike Captains with Bootstrapper tendencies. Keep Captains with Crusader or Heart tendencies.
archetypes.defense_strategy: Strike Captains with Crusader tendencies. Keep Captains with Bootstrapper or Calculator tendencies.

archetypes.one_liner: Follower who votes with the majority - essentially a blank ballot
archetypes.core_belief: I don't have strong opinions. I'll defer to people who seem more confident or knowledgeable.
archetypes.in_deliberation: Will speak rarely, agree quickly with confident voices, and vote with the majority. Won't resist social pressure.
recognize_by: Vague or noncommittal answers in voir dire
Looks to others before answering
Service industry or subordinate job role
Anxious body language
Phrases like 'I guess' or 'whatever you think'
archetypes.key_insight: Chameleons amplify whatever majority exists. If you have strong advocates, Chameleons become extra votes for you.
archetypes.plaintiff_strategy: Keep if you have strong Crusaders or Hearts. Strike if defense has strong Captains or Bootstrappers.
archetypes.defense_strategy: Keep if you have strong Bootstrappers or Captains. Strike if plaintiff has strong Crusaders.

archetypes.one_liner: Personal experience dominates their thinking - direction depends on what happened to them
archetypes.core_belief: I've been through something similar. I know what this is really about.
archetypes.in_deliberation: Will project their experience onto the case. Has credibility from 'I've been there.' Nearly impossible to move from their position.
subtypes: SUED AND WON → Strong plaintiff advocate ('Justice is possible')
WANTED TO SUE BUT COULDN'T → Strong plaintiff advocate ('Give them what I never got')
WAS INJURED BUT DIDN'T SUE → Strong defense advocate ('I toughed it out, so should they')
WAS SUED THEMSELVES → Strong defense advocate ('Plaintiffs are liars seeking money')
recognize_by: Mentions personal injury, lawsuit, or similar experience
Strong emotional reaction to case facts
Detailed knowledge of recovery or legal process
Phrases like 'I've been through this' or 'I know what that's like'
archetypes.plaintiff_strategy: Keep Scarred jurors who sued successfully. Strike those who were defendants or chose not to sue.
archetypes.defense_strategy: Keep Scarred jurors who were defendants or stoically didn't sue. Strike those who sued and won.

archetypes.one_liner: Numbers-focused analyst - skeptical of anything that can't be measured
archetypes.core_belief: Decisions should be based on data and methodology, not emotion or sympathy. Show me the numbers.
archetypes.in_deliberation: Will question damage calculations, discount emotional testimony, and push for 'reasonable' (lower) numbers. May create spreadsheets.
recognize_by: STEM, finance, or accounting background
Questions like 'What's the basis for that number?'
Discomfort with subjective claims
Higher education in quantitative field
Precision in language
archetypes.plaintiff_strategy: Can be won with strong expert methodology. Emphasize economic damages over non-economic. Strike if case relies on pain/suffering.
archetypes.defense_strategy: Keep. They'll reduce damages even if they find liability.

archetypes.one_liner: Empathy-driven - feels the plaintiff's pain and wants to help
archetypes.core_belief: This person has suffered. They deserve compassion and compensation. Money can help them heal.
archetypes.in_deliberation: Will advocate for plaintiff, push for high non-economic damages, and may become emotional. Will humanize the plaintiff's story.
recognize_by: Helping profession (nursing, counseling, teaching, ministry)
Emotional language and visible reactions
References to family, children, suffering
Strong religious faith emphasizing compassion
Phrases like 'I can only imagine' or 'think about their family'
archetypes.plaintiff_strategy: Keep as many as possible. They'll fight for high damages.
archetypes.defense_strategy: Strike if possible. They've already connected emotionally with plaintiff.

archetypes.one_liner: Hidden agenda - presents as neutral but has strong secret bias
archetypes.core_belief: I have strong feelings I'm not sharing because I want to be on this jury.
archetypes.in_deliberation: Will seem reasonable initially, then reveal true position. May be impossible to move once revealed.
subtypes: STEALTH PLAINTIFF → Presents as moderate, actually hates corporations (hidden grudge, family harmed)
STEALTH DEFENSE → Presents as moderate, actually hates lawsuits (tort reform believer, industry ties)
recognize_by: Answers that seem 'too perfect' or rehearsed
Evasive about relevant personal experiences
Inconsistencies between background and stated views
Seems eager to be on jury despite inconvenience
archetypes.key_insight: Hard to detect in voir dire. Look for mismatches between occupation/background and stated neutrality.
archetypes.strategy: Dig deeper in voir dire. Ask about family experiences, not just personal. Watch for evasion.

archetypes.one_liner: Wildcard who may ignore the law entirely - follows conscience over instructions
archetypes.core_belief: I answer to a higher authority than the judge. My conscience/God/principles come first.
archetypes.in_deliberation: May refuse to follow jury instructions. Can cause hung jury. Nearly impossible to persuade once position is set.
subtypes: MORAL NULLIFIER → Decides based on personal sense of justice, may ignore law
ANTI-GOVERNMENT → Rejects regulations as illegitimate, won't enforce them
ANTI-LAWSUIT ABSOLUTIST → Believes all lawsuits are wrong, won't award anything regardless of evidence
recognize_by: Statements about conscience or principles over law
Questions legitimacy of legal system or instructions
History of civil disobedience or extreme activism
Extreme positions on either political end
Hesitation when asked if they can follow judge's instructions
archetypes.key_insight: Often challengeable for cause based on their own statements. Ask directly: 'Could you follow an instruction you disagreed with?'
archetypes.strategy: Identify and challenge for cause. Too unpredictable for either side.
